A mental disorder, also referred to as a mental illness or psychiatric disorder, is a behavioral or mental pattern that causes significant distress or impairment of personal functioning.SYMPTOM(139,147)mental disorder0.3mental illness0.3psychiatric disorder0.3mental disorders0.0SYMPTOM(151,161)mental disorder0.3mental illness0.3psychiatric disorder0.3

According to DSM IV, a mental disorder is a psychological syndrome or pattern that is associated with distress (e.g. via a painful symptom), disability (impairment in one or more important areas of functioning), increased risk of death, or causes a significant loss of autonomy; however, it excludes normal responses such as grief from loss of a loved one and also excludes deviant behavior for political, religious, or societal reasons not arising from a dysfunction in the individual.SYMPTOM(141,151)mental disease0.0psychological disorder0.0mental illness0.0mental health condition0.0psychiatric disorder0.0mental disorders0.0mental disorder1.0depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0SYMPTOM(102,110)mental disorder1.0mental illness0.0psychiatric disorder0.0mental disorders0.0SYMPTOM(153,163)mental disorder1.0mental illness0.0psychiatric disorder0.0SYMPTOM(123,130)mental disorder1.0

Stigma and discrimination can add to the suffering and disability associated with mental disorders, leading to various social movements attempting to increase understanding and challenge social exclusion.SYMPTOM(55,65)mental disease0.0psychological disorder0.0mental illness0.0mental health condition0.0psychiatric disorder0.0mental disorders0.5mental disorder0.5depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0SYMPTOM(187,203)mental disorders1.0

In addition, the public perception of the level of disability associated with mental disorders can change.SYMPTOM(51,61)mental disease0.0psychological disorder0.0mental illness0.0mental health condition0.0psychiatric disorder0.0mental disorders0.5mental disorder0.5depressive disorder0.0communicable diseases0.0accidental injuries0.0

We have a package here of five symptoms—mild depression, some anxiety, fatigue, somatic pains, and obsessive thinking.SYMPTOM(65,72)mania0.0paranoia0.0depression0.5reactive disorder0.0mild depression0.5anxiety disorder0.0personality disorder0.0diabetes0.0schizophrenia0.0substance abuse disorder0.0SYMPTOM(83,96)mild depression1.0SYMPTOM(74,81)mild depression0.5depression0.5

Studying comorbidity between disorders have demonstrated two latent (unobserved) factors or dimensions in the structure of mental disorders that are thought to possibly reflect etiological processes.SYMPTOM(169,176)mental disorders1.0

Commonly recognized categories include specific phobias, generalized anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder, panic disorder, agoraphobia, obsessive compulsive disorder and post traumatic stress disorder.SYMPTOM(128,139)specific phobias0.2panic disorder0.2post traumatic stress disorder0.2generalized anxiety disorder0.2obsessive compulsive disorder0.2social anxiety disorder0.2

Bipolar disorder (also known as manic depression) involves abnormally "high" or pressured mood states, known as mania or hypomania, alternating with normal or depressed moods.SYMPTOM(32,37)mania0.5depression0.5SYMPTOM(121,130)mania0.5depression0.5

A number of different personality disorders are listed, including those sometimes classed as eccentric, such as paranoid, schizoid and schizotypal personality disorders; types that have described as dramatic or emotional, such as antisocial, borderline, histrionic or narcissistic personality disorders; and those sometimes classed as fear related, such as anxious avoidant, dependent, or obsessive compulsive personality disorders.SYMPTOM(230,240)obsessive compulsive personality0.5personality disorders0.5

There is an emerging consensus that personality disorders, similar to personality traits in general, incorporate a mixture of acute dysfunctional behaviors that may resolve in short periods, and maladaptive temperamental traits that are more enduring.SYMPTOM(207,220)personality disorders1.0SYMPTOM(70,88)personality disorders1.0SYMPTOM(176,189)personality disorders1.0

Various behavioral addictions, such as gambling addiction, may be classed as a disorder.SYMPTOM(19,29)gambling addiction1.0

Some examples include autism spectrum disorder, oppositional defiant disorder and conduct disorder, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which may continue into adulthood.SYMPTOM(122,135)autism0.3conduct disorder0.3oppositional defiant disorder0.3

Symptoms of schizophrenia typically manifest from late adolescence to early twenties.SYMPTOM(55,66)schizophrenia1.0

These challenges came from psychiatrists like Thomas Szasz who argued that mental illness was a myth used to disguise moral conflicts; from sociologists such as Erving Goffman who said that mental illness was merely another example of how society labels and controls non conformists; from behavioral psychologists who challenged psychiatry's fundamental reliance on unobservable phenomena; and from gay rights activists who criticised the APA's listing of homosexuality as a mental disorder.SYMPTOM(124,133)mental illness0.5mental disorder0.5SYMPTOM(456,469)mental illness0.5mental disorder0.5

It can impinge on personal liberty and the right to choose, and carry the risk of abuse for political, social, and other reasons; yet it can potentially prevent harm to self and others, and assist some people in attaining their right to healthcare when they may be unable to decide in their own interests.SYMPTOM(295,304)abuse1.0

All human rights oriented mental health laws require proof of the presence of a mental disorder as defined by internationally accepted standards, but the type and severity of disorder that counts can vary in different jurisdictions.SYMPTOM(17,25)mental disorder1.0
The social stigma associated with mental disorders is a widespread problem.SYMPTOM(4,17)mental disorders1.0

"For millennia, society did not treat persons suffering from depression, autism, schizophrenia and other mental illnesses much better than slaves or criminals: they were imprisoned, tortured or killed".SYMPTOM(170,180)depression0.2mental illnesses0.2autism0.2schizophrenia0.2
Employment discrimination is reported to play a significant part in the high rate of unemployment among those with a diagnosis of mental illness.SYMPTOM(85,97)mental illness1.0
Efforts are being undertaken worldwide to eliminate the stigma of mental illness, although the methods and outcomes used have sometimes been criticized.SYMPTOM(56,62)stereotypes0.0mental illness1.0

Media coverage of mental illness comprises predominantly negative and pejorative depictions, for example, of incompetence, violence or criminality, with far less coverage of positive issues such as accomplishments or human rights issues.SYMPTOM(135,146)mental illness1.0

In addition, in the article,"Stigma and its Impact on Help Seeking for Mental Disorders: What Do We Know?" by George Schomerus and Matthias Angermeyer, it is affirmed that "Family doctors and psychiatrists have more pessimistic views about the outcomes for mental illnesses than the general public (Jorm et al.,1999), and mental health professionals hold more negative stereotypes about mentally ill patients, but, reassuringly, they are less accepting of restrictions towards them.SYMPTOM(216,227)stereotypes0.5mental illnesses0.5

Despite public or media opinion, national studies have indicated that severe mental illness does not independently predict future violent behavior, on average, and is not a leading cause of violence in society.SYMPTOM(130,146)mental illness1.0

In a study of individuals diagnosed with "severe mental illness" living in a US inner city area, a quarter were found to have been victims of at least one violent crime over the course of a year, a proportion eleven times higher than the inner city average, and higher in every category of crime including violent assaults and theft.SYMPTOM(327,332)mental illness1.0

There are conflicting findings about the extent to which certain specific symptoms, notably some kinds of psychosis (hallucinations or delusions) that can occur in disorders such as schizophrenia, delusional disorder or mood disorder, are linked to an increased risk of serious violence on average.SYMPTOM(117,131)schizophrenia0.3mood disorder0.3delusional disorder0.3SYMPTOM(135,144)schizophrenia0.3mood disorder0.3delusional disorder0.3SYMPTOM(10,21)schizophrenia0.3mood disorder0.3delusional disorder0.3
